description: Learn Apache HTTP Server: The versatile, modular web server that powered the early web and is still widely used.

slides.title: What is Apache?
slides.content:
# The Veteran üéñÔ∏è

Apache HTTP Server (httpd).

Released in 1995. Played a key role in the initial growth of the World Wide Web.

Known for its flexibility, modularity, and `.htaccess` file support.

slides.title: Architecture
slides.content:
# Modules üß©

Apache is process-based (vs Nginx's event-based).

Functionality is added via **DSO** (Dynamic Shared Objects).

- `mod_rewrite`: URL rewriting.
- `mod_ssl`: HTTPS support.
- `mod_proxy`: Proxying.

slides.title: .htaccess
slides.content:
# Decentralized Config üìÑ

Unique to Apache.

You can override server configuration on a per-directory basis using a `.htaccess` file.

Great for shared hosting where you don't have access to the main config.

slides.title: Directives
slides.content:
# Instructions üó£Ô∏è

Config is a set of directives.

```apache
DocumentRoot "/var/www/html"
Listen 80

<Directory "/var/www">
    AllowOverride None
    Require all granted
</Directory>
```

slides.title: Config Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which file allows you to override Apache configuration on a per-directory basis?

slides.title: MPMs
slides.content:
# Multi-Processing Modules ‚öôÔ∏è

How Apache handles connections.

1.  **Prefork:** One process per request. Safe for non-thread-safe PHP modules. High memory.
2.  **Worker:** Multithreaded. Lower memory.
3.  **Event:** Similar to Nginx. Best for high concurrency.

slides.title: Rewrites (mod_rewrite)
slides.content:
# URL Magic ü™Ñ

Changing the requested URL on the fly.

```apache
RewriteEngine On
# Redirect old.html to new.html
RewriteRule ^old\.html$ new.html [R=301,L]
```

slides.title: Virtual Hosts
slides.content:
# Multiple Sites üèôÔ∏è

```apache
<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName example.com
    DocumentRoot /var/www/example
</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName blog.com
    DocumentRoot /var/www/blog
</VirtualHost>
```

slides.title: Security
slides.content:
# Hardening üõ°Ô∏è

- Disable directory listing (`Options -Indexes`).
- Hide server version (`ServerTokens Prod`).
- Restrict access.

```apache
<Directory "/admin">
    Require ip 10.0.0.1
</Directory>
```

slides.title: Apache vs Nginx
slides.content:
# The Rivalry ü•ä

- **Apache:** Flexible, `.htaccess`, Dynamic Modules. Slower under massive load.
- **Nginx:** Faster, Event-driven, Static content king, Reverse Proxy. No `.htaccess`.

Common setup: Nginx as Proxy -> Apache as App Server.

slides.title: Code Example
slides.content:
# .htaccess Config üíª

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
# Enable Rewriting
RewriteEngine On

# Force HTTPS
RewriteCond %{HTTPS} off
RewriteRule ^(.*)$ https://%{HTTP_HOST}%{REQUEST_URI} [L,R=301]

# Disable Directory Listing
Options -Indexes

# Block access to .env files
<Files .env>
    Order allow,deny
    Deny from all
</Files>
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Apache üéì

The Flexible Giant.

- **Modules:** `mod_rewrite`, `mod_ssl`.
- **.htaccess:** Per-folder config.
- **VirtualHosts:** Hosted sites.
- **MPM:** Prefork vs Worker vs Event.
- **LAMP Stack:** Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP.
